senses.de: The place where someone lives or works, which is used for sending letters, etc. to them.

Tips.title: Postal Communication
Tips.description: An address allows for sending and receiving mail, packages, and critical documents physically.
Tips.example: I updated my address to receive bank statements at my new location.

Tips.title: Online Shopping
Tips.description: E-commerce sites require your address to deliver items you purchase online.
Tips.example: Don't forget to provide your apartment number in your shipping address.

senses.de: To talk or write to someone to gain attention or to express something.
senses.ex: He addressed the audience before the play began.

Tips.title: Public Speaking
Tips.description: When you address a group, it implies public speaking, often formal and planned.
Tips.example: She will address the meeting on behalf of her team.

Tips.title: Attention Getter
Tips.description: To address can signal the start of communication, calling listeners' attention first.
Tips.example: Please address the class before starting your presentation.

senses.de: A formal speech that is given to a group.
senses.ex: The queen gave a televised address to the nation.

Tips.title: Formal Occasion
Tips.description: An address, like a speech, is often given on formal events, needing preparation.
Tips.example: The commencement address inspired graduating students.

senses.de: To think about, attempt to do or aware of a situation and try to deal with it.
senses.ex: We need to address the problem of obesity in children.

Tips.title: Problem Solving
Tips.description: Addressing a situation implies actively working to resolve it.
Tips.example: She addressed the feedback promptly and efficiently.

senses.de: The name or details that are used to send an email to a person's electronic mailbox.

Tips.title: Digital Identity
Tips.description: Email addresses identify you online and are required for internet communication.
Tips.example: I use a professional email address for job applications.

Tips.title: Internet Navigation
Tips.description: Web addresses, like URLs, help you find websites and navigate the internet.
Tips.example: Check the web address is correct if the page doesn't load.

senses.de: The way a person stands or positions themselves ready to play the ball in some sports, such as golf.
senses.ex: Her address of the ball was impeccable.

Tips.title: Sports Stance
Tips.description: In golf, 'address the ball' refers to taking the correct position before swinging.
Tips.example: He took a moment to properly address the ball.

Abode.wordDefinition:
Abode refers to a place where someone lives, like a home, a house or an apartment.

For example, if someone asks where you live, you would answer with your abode, like "I live in a house down the street." If someone asks for your address, you would give them the specific location of your abode such as "123 Main St., Anytown, USA."

Direction.wordDefinition:
Direction refers to the way in which something or someone is moving or facing. It could be north, south, east or west, or left or right.

Address points to a location while direction points to a way or path.

Domicile.wordDefinition:
Domicile refers to a person's legal residence, which can be different from their actual physical address.

Domicile is typically used in legal documents or government forms, and it determines things like tax obligations and voting rights.

In simpler terms, address is where someone lives, while domicile is their legal home base.

Dwell.wordDefinition:
It is used when you need to give someone directions to where you live or work. Dwell typically refers to living in a particular place or residence, like a home or apartment.

It is used when talking about where someone lives or stays. Address is applicable when you want to give or receive directions, whereas dwell is applicable when you want to talk about where someone lives.

Lecture.wordDefinition:
Lecture refers to a talk given by a teacher or an expert on a specific topic.

Essentially, an address is a speech given to convey important information or messages, whereas a lecture is a talk given to educate or teach an audience.

Location.wordDefinition:
Address and location are two different terms used to describe a place. An address is a unique identification of a place, consisting of street name, number, city, and state.

Location describes the physical position or coordinates of a place on the earth's surface.

In simpler terms, an address is like a name for a place, while location is more like its geographical position on a map.

Addresses are used for mailing or visiting a place, while location is useful for navigation or finding nearby places.

Residence.wordDefinition:
Residence refers to the place where a person lives, usually their home. It may or may not be the same as their mailing or business address.

Address is a formal means of locating someone or something, whereas residence refers to the physical location where someone lives.

Speech.wordDefinition:
An address is a formal statement or message delivered to a group of people, often with a specific purpose or occasion, such as a speech given by a politician or a welcome address given at a conference.

A speech is a formal or public talk given by a person to convey information, persuade others, or express opinions on a particular topic or issue.

Speeches can vary in length and formality and can be given in various settings such as at a school assembly, a business conference, or a political rally.

An address is a formal statement or message delivered to a group of people or a physical location, while a speech is a formal or public talk given by a person on a particular topic or issue.

Street.wordDefinition:
Address refers to the location of a building, consisting of both the street name and the number assigned to the building.

Street refers only to the road or thoroughfare that the building is located on. For example, if someone asked for your address, you would give them a specific number on a specific street.

The street is just the name of the road while the address is the specific location where someone can find a building.

quotes.Text: It's like breathing in and out to me. It's like having a conversation with someone who isn't there. Because it has to be addressed to somebody - not a particular person, or very rarely.
quotes.Title: Scottish Poet
quotes.Name: Norman MacCaig

quotes.Text: While I have some regrets that this is my last opportunity to deliver a State of the State address, I appreciate and am humbled by the opportunities this great state has given me.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Jane D. Hull

quotes.Text: It's a real concern of mine every day. What can we do? How much can we do? How quickly can we address all these important things?
quotes.Title: Canadian Businessman
quotes.Name: Jeffrey Skoll

quotes.Text: Any art worthy of its name should address 'life', 'man', 'nature', 'death' and 'tragedy'.
quotes.Title: American Artist
quotes.Name: Barnett Newman

quotes.Text: Every player is motivated by different things and needs to be addressed accordingly.
quotes.Title: German Coach
quotes.Name: Julian Nagelsmann

quotes.Text: People like to invent enemies. It spares us the need to address complex worldviews.
quotes.Title: Israeli Politician
quotes.Name: Yair Lapid

quotes.Text: It's very rare, as an actor, to be someplace - to have an address, so to speak.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Yvette Nicole Brown

quotes.Text: When you write poetry you are always addressing the world somehow.
quotes.Title: English Poet
quotes.Name: John Cooper Clarke

quotes.Text: We footballers don't address one another as 'My dear.
quotes.Title: French Athlete
quotes.Name: Karim Benzema

quotes.Text: I'm not afraid to address anything ever.
quotes.Title: American Coach
quotes.Name: Metta World Peace
